body:
The PR of uploading `libdarknet_mac2.0.so` is posted [here](https://github.com/dmlc/web-data/pull/211).

After you merge the PR above, there is no need to modify `from_darknet.py`. you can close this PR. Thanks for everybody's help! :)

-Hao
@icemelon9 Did you get a chance to work on the comments?
Thanks will merge that one in once the PR in the other repo is merged.
@hlu1 @wweic I had addressed the reviewr's comment. care to give some more review or approve?
@MarisaKirisame looks good to me. do you mind fixing VM as well?
@tqchen modified per comments.

@wweic the VM error is caused by memory leak in the executable. It has already been fixed by #4100 !
you can verify simply by calling vm.evaluate/execute multiple time in one of the test, and open htop. It will leak before 4100 but wont after 4100.

@MarisaKirisame Oh, I was referring the opcode `AllocClosure` in vm. https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/a7404230695bf774be26a25a30fd9b3fe204b18f/src/runtime/vm/vm.cc#L947-L952

Right now it doesn't behave the same as what you are doing in this pr, and it should has memory leak for the same cause i think?
@wweic the vm doesnt support local recursion.
Thanks @yzhliu !
fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/4147
Overall LGTM, let's wait for other reviewers' updates as well.
Ping @srkreddy1238 @yongwww @icemelon9 @zhiics for review and merging.
Thanks @broune @anijain2305 @wweic. This is now merged.
Thanks for reporting the problem, the community uses https://discuss.tvm.ai/ for trouble shooting, please open a new thread there.
Thanks for reporting the problem, the community uses https://discuss.tvm.ai/ for trouble shooting, please open a new thread there.

`libdarknet_mac2.0.so` is uploaded in this [PR](https://github.com/dmlc/web-data/pull/211).

After the above shared library is uploaded to the correct path in `from_darknet.py`, there is no need to modify `from_darknet.py`, so I restored this file. There is no file changed in this PR.

-Hao
Ping - would someone be able to take a look at this again?

Thanks a lot for working on this, this is going to be really impactful, especially toward supporting NLP models. I have a couple of questions:

1. Can you please explain the shape function in a little more detail? What exactly is its purpose? Will it have to be registered for every op?
2. Some ops, like `full`, take their shape argument as a constant list. With this change, we could potentially support either a constant list or a relay expression that is unknown at compile time. How would that work? Would the operator definition have to change?
thanks @kevinthesun can you comment a bit on how did the change fix the problem?
Thanks for the proposal. One high level comment: ideally we want to keep the module API minimum, and move transformation-like operations to the transform namespace :)
Thanks @soiferj, this is now merged.

How about the backward compatibility to 1.12 or 1.14 while upgrading to 2.0 ?

One easy solution is to use TF upgrade script and convert to 2.0 and use it, but it may not be more native to 2.0 features.

- Do we drop old version and go to 2.0 ?
- Maintain both
        1. Move old frontend to compatibility (relay.frontend.compatibility.from_tensorflow)? What would be CI default version ? Validating both test cases here may be a challenge !
        2. Selectively change behaviour based on ```tf.__version__```

Any ideas @tqchen @tmoreau89 @yongwww @soiferj ?

@MarisaKirisame isn't local recursion a feature of relay instead of being part of an implementation of relay runtime? But I think vm compiler might need to handle it differently, I'm ok putting it in a separate PR.

# Node System Refactor Proposal

This proposal is part of the unified object protocol RFC. The node refers to the base object structure for constructing AST/IR nodes as well as utilities manipulating them in the TVM stack.

Historically, the node folder contains an implementation of a smart pointer(NodePtr), a base object(Node) and a base reference type(NodeRef). On top of these data structures, we provide runtime checking and conversion. These features are now replaced by runtime::Object which allows further reuse by other runtime object types.

Besides the basic features provided by runtime::Object. We also provided additional features for AST/IR nodes. The important ones include:

- Reflection: being able to quickly access any field of the node into frontends(e.g. python).
- Serialization: any node objects can be serialized to json.
- Pretty printing: we can print out most of the node objects.

On one side, we could just put support for these features into runtime(e.g. make them part of Object). However, we need to keep in mind that the runtime needs to be minimum. Additionally, these features are mainly for building compiler infra.

Some of these features are previously scattered in the project, outside the node directory.
We propose to consolidate them into a centralized location -- the node folder.
These features are implemented in a dialect independent manner and serves as base infra for compiler.

## Remove vtable from Base Node

The current implementation of node reflection system requires child classes to override  a virtual function VisitAttrs. As mentioned in the unified object protocol proposal, one of our design goal is to remove vtable from common AST/IR Node classes. By doing so, these node classes can be directly exposed to other languages via C ABI -- which allows direct access to the fields of the node.

We offer an alternative solution to the c++ vtable by a columnar dispatch table indexed by the type index of the object. The data structure, ReflectionVTable, is a global singleton that keeps record of the key reflection-related functions for each object type. These functions are registered by TVM_REGISTER_NODE_TYPE. Note that we already use a similar data structure for node creation, we propose to unify them together. This change does requires a refactor to remove the final keyword from VisitAttrs functions(as they are no longer virtual).

We do not, however, forbid use of virtual functions for all node sub-classes. We only aim to expose the core IR/AST nodes for now. The sub-classes with virtual functions will still work fine as ususal as long as we do not want to expose them via ABI.

## PR
- https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/4189

Cross posting from RFC #4116 

# Node System Refactor Proposal

This proposal is part of the unified object protocol RFC. The node refers to the base object structure for constructing AST/IR nodes as well as utilities manipulating them in the TVM stack.

Historically, the node folder contains a implementation of a smart pointer(NodePtr), a base object(Node) and a base reference type(NodeRef). On top of these data structures, we provide runtime checking and conversion. These features are now replaced by runtime::Object which allows further reuse by other runtime object types.

Besides the basic features provided by runtime::Object. We also provided additional features for AST/IR nodes. The important ones include:

- Reflection: being able to quickly access any field of the node into frontends(e.g. python).
- Serialization: any node objects can be serialized to json.
- Pretty printing: we can print out most of the node objects.

On one side, we could just put support for these features into runtime(e.g. make them part of Object). However, we need to keep in mind that the runtime needs to be minimum. Additionally, these features are mainly for building compiler infra.

Some of these features are previously scattered in the project, outside the node directory.
We propose to consolidate them into a centralized location -- the node folder.
These features are implemented in a dialect independent manner and serves as base infra for compiler.

## Remove vtable from Base Node

The current implementation of node reflection system requires child classes to override  a virtual function VisitAttrs. As mentioned in the unified object protocol proposal, one of our design goal is to remove vtable from common AST/IR Node classes. By doing so, these node classes can be directly exposed to other languages via C ABI -- which allows direct access to the fields of the node.

We offer an alternative solution to the c++ vtable by a columnar dispatch table indexed by the type index of the object. The data structure, ReflectionVTable, is a global singleton that keeps record of the key reflection-related functions for each object type. These functions are registered by TVM_REGISTER_NODE_TYPE. Note that we already use a similar data structure for node creation, we propose to unify them together. This change does requires a refactor to remove the final keyword from VisitAttrs functions(as they are no longer virtual).

We do not, however, forbid use of virtual functions for all node sub-classes. We only aim to expose the core IR/AST nodes for now. The sub-classes with virtual functions will still work fine as ususal as long as we do not want to expose them via ABI.
cc @dmlc/tvm-committer
@wweic the lambda lifting pass and the vm compiler need to deal with recursion. However none of them does.
good catch, can you send a PR to fix the problem?

@MarisaKirisame Yes. I'll create an issue.

I have approved, cc @jroesch @icemelon9 @tqchen @hlu1 to review and merge.
cc @jwfromm
ok
Sorry about the problem. It is due to the fact that we may have some old CPU instance. I will wait until we have a runtime check for CPU to check it in again.
I think if we look at my recent PR we need to probably track the device context when we allocate storage. The storage's context will prevent merging different pieces of storage.
I checked the functionality locally. Unfortunately the functionality check cant be put into tests because the test requires skylake or cascadelake machine.

@soiferj For ```full``` op, we can change the input shape argument to be relay.Expr. We use hybrid script to register shape functions, since most of them are not easy to be written as tensor expression. We only add CPU version shape functions, and relay on Heterogeneous execution for gpu.
@tqchen Sure. Dispatch function doesn't need to couple with relay::Module.
Yeah, we need to have the runtime check for CPU micro-architecture, so that tests can be skipped on the processors that are not supported.

@tqchen The original implementation does division before reduce sum, which causes numerical error comparing to numpy.mean higher than rtol(10e-5) when input size is large. Now I changed it to sum first, which is consistent with avg_pool2d implementation.
@jroesch thanks. I have put references to the PR in the RFC.
It must be the miss-match of the Cuda used while compiling the TVM. For example, while compiling the TVM used different version and now your using different version of CUDA.
Thanks @kevinthesun
ping @ziyu-guo can you add a testcase for this?

Thanks everyone for the helpful discussion. The current proposed actionable item would be proceed with @yidawang 's option. Possibly also allow user to configure whether to set thread affinity via the threadpool configuration API.

We will keep the current default for now, but would be great to do some benchmarks to evaluate the effect of EAS on the systems, in particular android which was the topic being bought up
@eqy please let me know if it is ready to be merged. @yzhliu @kazum @srkreddy1238  can you help to do a quick review?
@yongwww please followup and https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/code_review.html#approve-and-request-changes-explicitly

ping @SWu please https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/code_review.html#approve-and-request-changes-explicitly 

@MarisaKirisame please add a brief description to the PR
ping @tristan-arm please follow up :)
close for now as we want to have a bit more powerful mixed precision computation rather than directly use fp16. We can come back to RFC discussions and open new PRs thanks @zxy844288792 !

@mbarrett97 I wonder why not just using the transfer learning in the AutoTVM. After using transfer learning, AutoTVM will skip the tasks that have been tried before. See the example at
https://docs.tvm.ai/tutorials/autotvm/tune_relay_arm.html#begin-tuning
superceded by https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/4056. Thanks @ZQPei  for your contribution
@tqchen - tristan is on holidays , the other PR by @ekalda in #4141 should supersede this work and I think this PR should be abandoned.
Close due to inactive status, I think this is a thread worth following up. with an RFC for debugger output schema and interaction with existing visualizers
You need a reviewer - @FrozenGene or @anijain2305 ?
ping @icemelon9
@ZihengJiang  @merrymercy can you also take a look into this PR?
@vinx13 please followup and let us know when it can be merged
Thanks @optima2005 @zhiics
@vinx13 It would be good if you could review this. This one is specifically to speedup Automatic Quantization, so review would be very helpful.
Thanks @inadob ! Next time please tag reviewers from the reviewer list
thanks @u99127 @tristan-arm @anijain2305

Here are the evaluation result on imagenet val, with rounding = "UPWARD" and KLD scales
```
Resnet18 v2
acc-top1=0.707080 acc-top5=0.898180
Resnet 50 v2
acc-top1=0.764980 acc-top5=0.931160
Resnet 18 v1
acc-top1=0.707360 acc-top5=0.897860
Resnet 50 v1
acc-top1=0.735740 acc-top5=0.915940
```
Accuracy drop is 0.1%~0.3%. 
Previous results are in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/3538

@anijain2305 @ZihengJiang Please take a look
Note that the nightly build will not be affected since KLD scales are not used.
Looks reasonable, @vinx13 can you also comment on the speedup? it would be great if you can also send a tutorial about using the quantization infra in a separate PR :)

Thanks @vinx13 The performance numbers should improve now, given we are avoiding casting to FP32 and than back to Int :) Moreover, from a quantized network perspective, keeping everything in int seems like the right thing to do (unless there is huge accuracy impact).

IMHO, both 1.x and 2.0 should be maintained for a while, most of the working tf models were built on top of 1.x. Another option is to maintain the same from_tensorflow for both 1.x and 2.0, it is possible to maintain it for both since savedmodel is the universal format, not sure how much work is needed. For TVM CI, maybe we can build different container for this kind of backward compatability testing. @tqchen
Sure will do
Thanks @MarisaKirisame @wweic @hlu1. This is now merged
Thanks @Hzfengsy @vinx13 @minminsun @soiferj
Close it for now. Fell free to reopen if this issue pops up again.
@zhiics @kevinthesun @kazum, would any of you be able to take a look at this PR?

Just wanted to note that I implemented this op in parallel and have it included in PR #4197. There are few differences in our implementations and I'm open to removing my take on it if we decide this version is better.

Key differences are I use full instead of tile and I don't special case when initially parsing the nodes to extract inputs. Using full requires a static shape instead of a dynamic one so I use infer_value to convert the input. The trade-off is that my implementation is likely a little slower to convert but will be faster during inference.
Thanks, indeed the fix was applied outside of this repo; and results in no changes necessary on this one. I will consequently close this PR.
Thanks for working on this! This is a huge improvement. Which implementation of BERT are you testing this change against?
@tqchen @tmoreau89 what do you mean by description? I had edited the PR comment, if that is what u mean.
This is tested against both versions of [BERT-squad](https://github.com/onnx/models/tree/master/text/machine_comprehension/bert-squad).
I'm interested in this. @wweic I'll talk to you for advice.

Google seems to push for using TF2.x, perhaps to "catch up" on popularity against PyTorch and the like on developer happiness? Still I support @yongwww's point: Existing work outside Google is on TF 1.x (and 0.x :-)), and they will linger for some time. So this PR, and the sub-PR about fixing the tutorial target full backward compatibility, using the `tf.compat.v1` APIs for now. Having said and done so, a couple comments:

* The new annotations like `@tf.function` really change a lot of syntax, and maintaining a single script for both 1.x and 2.x would be a pain for developers and users. We can detect at runtime what TF version is packaged, and switch script accordingly (e.g. a facade `from_tensorflow` module that loads the right implementation) (well, same as @srkreddy1238's point (2)).
* Does it matter anyway? TVM users might be looking ahead, as the community is growing and penetrating systems in production. It may be bold but saner to concentrate all strengths on what is clearly the close future: TF2.x.

Thanks for the comments @yongwww  & @ic 

As @yongwww said, front end implementation may not get affected much as the savedmodel is universal except the operator specific API changes in 2.0. TF 2.0 has major modification in terms of  the way we build the graph and execute (session, eager execution, tf.function ..etc.). Test cases will demand more effort here.

I would suggest dual compatibility by
- Selectively switching at frontend implementation.
- Individual test cases to 1.x and 2.0.
- Necessary documentation or tutorial to promote TF 2.0 in coming days.

Thanks for this proposal! For Yolo and ssd, does the performance advantage mainly come from larger tuning space? If so, I suggest we also do full auto-tuning with expanded tuning space, so that we have an apple to apple comparison, and a more clear picture about tuning time vs performance trade-off. Also it would be interesting to see how this method can be used to select representative schedules for dynamic shape workloads.
Thanks @anijain2305 @tmoreau89 @yzhliu @vinx13 This PR is now merged.

The leftmost two columns in the table are the total tuning time of 2,000 trials each op and the final inference latency, respectively. With XGBoost tuner, I suppose the result after 2,000 trials is sufficient to illustrate the usability of selective tuning. Comparing to the full auto-tuning result could definitely be interesting, but it is time-consuming since the tuning space is the order of 10^5 for each op. I'll further study the tuning space coverage in the short future for sure, along with the dynamic shape codegen supports. (In fact, this RFC is more like a side application during the process of dynamic shape codegen investigation 😄 )
Thanks for reporting the problem, the community uses the discuss forum for troubleshooting please open a new troubleshooting thread on https://discuss.tvm.ai
Good catch, please feel free to open a new PR

Thanks for the proposal. I think overall this can be categorized into schedule of the tasks. Also vc @eqy Would be nice if we can come up with abstractions for a generic task schedule strategy, then add it as a modular plugin.

The networkx dependency is something that worth discussing. Ideally we want to minimize dependencies of the core autotvm package.
you can just go into the TensorFlow graph and pop out the attributes which create the errors. for example half_pixel_centers and then it works fine, I have faced these errors too

you can just get the graph of the TensorFlow and then pop the arguments inside the graph and then you can feed the graph and to the TVM. this will work.  also, you can add the adding ignores=['explicit_paddings'] to the main function but it gives rise to other errors further...

> Just wanted to note that I implemented this op in parallel and have it included in PR #4197. There are few differences in our implementations and I'm open to removing my take on it if we decide this version is better.
> 
> Key differences are I use full instead of tile and I don't special case when initially parsing the nodes to extract inputs. Using full requires a static shape instead of a dynamic one so I use infer_value to convert the input. The trade-off is that my implementation is likely a little slower to convert but will be faster during inference.

Hi @jwfromm 

Thanks for the notification. 
I think we might need to invite the reviewers to discuss the differences and trade-off.

@tqchen Thanks for the comments and you're right. One important message behind this investigation is a schedule should be shared across ops with differernt attributes.

For the networkx dependency, I have the same concern as well. I used it to build a graph and find maximum cliques in the graph. Unfortunately, I didn't find any existing TVM dependency can achieve the desire functionality. On the other hand, we can also use different algorithm such as K-Means to cluster tasks, so that the existing dependency, `sklearn`, would be sufficient, although the result of using K-Means is not as good as the one I showed. I would be happy to take your suggestion if any.
cc @tqchen

If anyone is interested, you can find my BERT test script [here](https://github.com/jwfromm/tvm/blob/onnx_model_test/tests/python/frontend/onnx/test_bert/run_onnx_bert.py). The script shows how to run a question answering bert and displays the results in human readable text.
`Any` is used for dynamic representation, how about using `reduce_any` here? @icemelon9
Are you referring to the TF op or the TVM op? For the TVM op, I was referencing `All`, which has the same semantics.
If we make the code modular enough via high level scheduling(planning api), the networkx dep could be an optional once for those who want to use the component, which might help alleviate the issue

> Are you referring to the TF op or the TVM op? For the TVM op, I was referencing `All`, which has the same semantics.

 Yeah, any is quite similar to All, but the name `Any` is used in TVM already, you can find it via `relay.Any(`. I meant we can consider using a different name for this op in tvm instead of `any` to avoid confusion.
I see, yes I can change the op name if everyone thinks that's worthwhile.
Thanks for all the great discussions, as the original problem is resolved. I am going to close this, future discussions are encouraged in https://discuss.tvm.ai/
pls make sure u r follow https://docs.tvm.ai/install/from_source.html
